description.narrative: As part of IFCs Critical Commodities Finance Program Phase II (CCFP II), IFC is proposing the following project: 1) an expansion of the funded risk-sharing facility (CCFP SocGen, Project No. 34955) with Société Générale SA (SocGenor the Bank); 2) an extension of the maturity of the facility from March 2014 to January 2015. The US$150 million increase would supplement IFCs existing US$250 million investment in the facility, bringing up IFCs total participation up to US$400 million in SocGens trade and commodity finance portfolio of the critical agriculture and energy commodities/inputs. CCFP program is a public-private partnership (PPP) initiative that is part of IFCs multi-faceted rapid global financial crisis response. It is aiming at mitigating disruptions in two critical commodity value chains: (i) exports and imports of agricultural commodities and inputs globally; and (ii) imports of energy products into IDA or IDA- blend countries.

The CCFP-Bank facility is expected to have the following specific development impacts: - Increase Liquidity: The Facility will ensure continuing and additional funding to the major agricultural and energy sectors in Emerging Countries, especially in Africa and IDA countries. This Facility will contribute to the Bank maintaining its level of business in commodity finance. Among other things, the Facility will enable traders to purchase from and finance agricultural producers, the mainstay of most economies in Africa, and ensure food security and income for the public at large, but especially to farmers. - Strong Demonstration Effect by catalyzing other IFIs to Support Agri and Energy Finance: By supporting commodity backed finance and outreach in partnerships with banks, the facility will have a significant demonstration impact on other banks, especially local /regional banks to participate in funding the agricultural and energy sectors. This would ultimately help increase access to finance for critical economic sectors. - A steady supply of critically needed refined oil products through regular channels will keep prices in check, remove parallel market incentives, improve affordability for the vulnerable poor and contribute to sustaining local economic activities.
